intro: Quercus aquatica var. cuneata, commonly known as the narrow-leaf water oak, is a variant of the water oak native to the southeastern United States. It is a deciduous tree characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 cm long. The plant produces small, clustered acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found near water sources such as rivers and wetlands. Its botanical features make it well adapted to humid, subtropical climates.
